Today marks the first hearing on DADT in over 17 years.... It is a major step forward in repealing this policy that has cost lives and has cost the careers of so many upstanding men and women in uniform.
 
 I won't answer in turn to those who mask their prejudice behind faith, or their bitter distaste behind fantasy and what if scenario's. I will however say this. 
 
 What someone does or is should not define the basis by which you serve. At the core of every person in uniform should or at least I hope would be a love for country. A personal zeal to focus and realize the fragility of our rights, and how central their service plays in affecting the lives of so many who have tasted freedom.
 
 Freedom and liberty does have a price. And it has been shed by the precious blood of the fallen from Valley Forge, to Iwo Jima, from the streets of Baghdad, to the Pacific Ocean... All of us here know exactly how much sacrifice means, yet many if us take such for granted, myself included.
 
 Knowing first hand the effect this policy has on lives of others not only myself, but that of my partner who now serves I can say that this issue is paramount. 
 
 Gays have fought since the days of the Revolution. We have fought not just the battles for our country, but those within ourselves. To those who would try and say this would hurt morale, or would somehow damage credibility to our service I ask you to take a good hard look at what you are implying.
 
 This is not a matter of benefits or some sort of hand out or special treatment. It is the right and the ability to serve and to die for your country. Not in guilt, shame, or persecution, but in clear conscience and with honor.
 
 Our blood has been spilled and has mingled with our strait brothers in arms. We have shed not just blood, but tears and we have denied ourselves for the greater cause and denied and even lied about who we are as people, and whom we love.
 
 To deny and to mislead is false. No longer can this policy exist. We cannot allow the poison of self guilt. the feeling of dishonor tarnish those whom serve now. And history will judge us in how we honor those who have fallen.
 
 Dare we judge those who have fallen in a different light because they love someone else? Would we dare to do the same to those because of a different shade of skin? Or because they pray to a different deity?
 
 Today, my partner serves in the closet. He serves silently, afraid and terrified if anyone finds out he's gay because he fears physical harm, or a dishonorable discharge.
 
 I hope that soon, this anxiety will go away, as well as the bitter prejudices and stigmas that we brand each other with, and the bitter distrust toward one another we as Americans have had for so long.
